Award.AwardTitle: Computational Methods for Heterogeneous Soft Living Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Biofilms are present everywhere in the natural world and can have beneficial or adverse health effects. Through this award the principal investigator will provide a solid modeling platform and develop and analyze the computational tools that are needed for better understanding the behavior of biofilm formation and interaction with the microenvironment. For example, biofilms can be present in water systems affecting pipes and filters, and they can also be found in chronic wounds and infected prosthetic joints and heart valves, causing resistance to antibiotic use and then requiring further surgical interventions and prosthesis replacement. The computational methods developed in this research will provide an additional inexpensive and powerful method that compliments the work done by experimentalists. The computational algorithms and software tools are sufficiently general that they may be applied to other problems in science and engineering that present similar challenges. An interesting example is to better understand how bacteriophage adhere to mucus as a way to provide a nonhost-derived immunity. Improved insights provided through computational modeling have the potential to lead to the creation of new kinds of antibiotics.

The principal investigator (PI) aims to develop numerical techniques for the solutions of equations that model heterogeneous soft living materials arising in biology. The focus is on biofilms and mucosal surfaces, and their interactions with surrounding fluid and biological agents, e.g. bacteria and viruses. Multiphase living materials are characterized by adhesive forces, they have viscoelastic properties and can diffuse, grow, deform or shear. The PI plans to focus on computational tools for solving the energy driven Cahn-Hilliard type equations describing phase separation and sharp diffusive interfaces, coupled with fluid flow equations. Interacting biological agents introduce heterogeneities and discontinuities into multiphase systems, highlighting the need for the design of a robust computational framework that couples continuous and discrete models. The PI aims to develop integrated methods for addressing challenges particular to heterogeneous biomaterials. He aims to combine high order discontinuous Galerkin finite element discretizations, in conjunction with time and spatial adaptivity, for analyzing the solution of the underlying systems while accounting for discontinuities, nonlinearities and moving sharp interior interfaces. Unconditionally energy stable and locally mass conservative schemes will be used to model long time dynamics. The resulting ill-conditioned nonlinear algebraic systems will be solved using efficient solvers based on multigrid techniques that exploit the specific local structure stemming from the choice of discretization. The development of computational tools that resolve these issues can lead to a better understanding of the factors that impact the evolution of soft biological systems. The efficient nonlinear and spatiotemporally adaptive solvers proposed will apply to even more general equations and will therefore advance the field of numerical nonlinear partial differential equations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we developed a computational framework and tools for the simulation of heterogeneous soft living materials. Even though these soft living materials have different biological characteristics, a common modeling framework describes their behavior.

 Some examples of these biological porous materials include mucus, biofilms, cartilage and tumor tissues. These multiphase materials have different components which interact with each other through their interfaces, they are characterized by adhesive forces between homogeneous components, they have viscoelastic properties and can diffuse, grow, deform or shear. Biomaterials are generically heterogeneous. For instance, consider mucus, a viscoelastic and adhesive porous gel that protects the lung airways, gastrointestinal tract, vagina, eye and other mucosal surfaces. Mucins are large polymers secreted at high concentrations which then slowly diffuse and dilute outwards from the epithelium interacting with water, creating a porous hydrogel with progressively larger size pores, until the mucins become so sparse that they can be sloughed off due to shear force and fluid flow. On the other hand, imbalances in mucus mechanics can lead to debilitating diseases like cystic fibrosis, a genetic condition that affects the lungs and makes the patient susceptible to microbial infections. In addition, other biological materials like biofilms and tumors also exhibit growth, generally, in highly heterogeneous ways. Soft living materials, like biofilms, are ubiquitously found in natural and industrial environments and are responsible for conditions such as chronic wounds and corrosion of fuel pipes. Hence, it is important to obtain a better understanding of the complex turn-over dynamics governing the various soft biological materials.

We developed efficient algorithms and software, for the accurate solution of key continuous equations appearing in mathematical models describing the dynamics of soft porous heterogeneous biological materials. Computational tools were also developed for the incorporation of discrete biological agents like isolated bacterial colonies into the underlying systems. We developed integrated methods for addressing challenges particular to heterogeneous biomaterials, including accurate solution of the coupled equations (discrete and continuous), a major challenge. In simulating diffusive interfaces, a very fine (comparable to the interfacial width) computational mesh is required along the steep interfacial edges that lead to high computational cost especially in three dimensions. Discontinuities, long time dynamics and resulting algebraic systems that are highly nonlinear and ill-conditioned require attention. The developed computational tools deal with these issues.

Mathematical analysis was performed on the developed algorithms to establish that they are stable and convergent to the solutions. And computational test and simulations have been carried to validate the theoretical results. The results have been and will be disseminated to the community via publications and conference presentations and also the developed software will be made available to interested researchers on PI's webpage.

 The developed efficient solvers are applicable to even more general equations thus advance the field of computational mathematics in general.
